metadata.case_name: Gillanders Arbuthnot & Co. (assessee firm) v. Commissioner of Income-tax (cross-appeals)

facts.text: The assessee is a registered firm carrying on business mostly as managing agents of number of companies. Till the end of February 1947, the firm consisted of four partners namely 1 A.C. Gladstone 2 S. D. Gladstone 3 T. S. Gladstone and 4 Glendye Limited, each having 30, 39, 30 and 1 shares respectively in the profits of the firm.
Assessment year 1947-48 for which the previous year was the financial year ended on March 31, 1947.

On February 28, 1947, the assessee firm through its partners entered into an agreement for sale of some of the shares and securities held by it in favour of Gillanders Arbuthnot Co. (the Company) for a sum of Rs. 75 lakhs.

Clause 2 of the agreement: In consideration of the sum of Rupees Fourteen Lakhs and Ninety thousand the existing partners shall admit the company as a partner in the firm... the share of the company in the goodwill and in the profits of the firm being ninety-nine per cent thereof.

Clause 3: The said two sums... shall be paid and satisfied as follows: As to Rs. Sixty-four lakhs and Ninety thousand by allotment of 64,900 Ordinary Shares of Rs.100 each fully paid; As to Rs. Twenty-five lakhs by allotment of 25,000 Redeemable Cumulative Preference Shares of Rs.100 each fully paid.

On the same day, February 28, 1947, the assessee firm was reconstituted and a new partnership came into existence consisting of five partners: 1 The Company 2 A.C. Gladstone 3 S. Gladstone 4 T.S. Gladstone 5 Glendye Limited. The Company had 99 per cent share in profits.

The Company was previously a private Ltd. Company. In 1946 it applied to convert to Public Ltd. and sell shares at premium. Examiner permitted ordinary shares at premium not exceeding Rs.125 per share and preference shares at not exceeding Rs.51 per share.
Original assessment made on August 28, 1948 on total income of Rs. 12,90,829.
Income-tax Officer initiated proceedings under s.34(1)(a) on May 2, 1949 and completed fresh assessment on January 16, 1956 bringing to charge capital gains at Rs. 1,03,16,786.
Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner who rejected challenge to s.34(1)(a), computed capital gains at Rs. 70,91,24.
Tribunal held capital gains at Rs. 46,76,784.

Calcutta High Court in Reference u/s 66(1): Answered first question affirmative for Revenue; split second question, first part affirmative for Revenue, second negative against Revenue; third question capital gains Rs. 27,04,772.
Original cost of shares and securities as on January 1, 1939 was Rs. 47,95,728.

At original assessment, partnership deed was before ITO but sale deed to Company was not; no material on value as on 1.1.1939 or sale for Rs.75 lakhs; return in old form without Pt.VII for capital gains.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the proceedings under section 34(1)(a) have been validly initiated

Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, any capital gains within the meaning of Section 12-B could be said to arise by the transaction involving transfer of the investments held by the assessee to the Company
Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was justified in law in computing the capital gains at Rs. 46,76,784

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings under s.34(1)(a) have not been validly initiated
To the facts of this case s.12-B is not attracted; transaction was merely a readjustment, not a sale

respondent_arguments.text: Proceedings under s.34(1)(a) validly initiated due to non-disclosure of material facts
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.34(1)(a); Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. ITO

respondent_arguments.text: Capital gains arose under s.12-B on transfer of investments; amount higher than High Court's computation
Transaction was a sale, not exchange or readjustment; full value should be market value

court_reasoning.text: Assessee failed to disclose fully and truly all material facts: sale deed not placed before ITO, no particulars of sale for Rs.75 lakhs or 1939 value, return without capital gains part. ITO had reason to believe escapement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Primary facts not disclosed; ITO to draw inferences. Cited Calcutta Discount Co., Hemchandra Kar, etc.

court_reasoning.text: Transaction is a sale per agreement Clause 1; payment by shares does not convert to exchange. Rejected Revenue's new contention of exchange and assessee's readjustment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substance is sale for Rs.75 lakhs; distinguished exchange cases like Ramakrishna Pillai.

court_reasoning.text: Full value of consideration is bargained price Rs.75 lakhs, not market value, as proviso to s.12-B(2) not attracted (transfer pre-dates section, no avoidance intent). Capital gains Rs.27,04,772 after deductions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited George Henderson: in sale, full value is actual sale price. No gains on goodwill.

holdings.text: Capital gains under s.12-B arose on transfer of shares/securities to Company for Rs.75 lakhs

precedents_cited.case_name: Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Companies District-1, Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of s.34(1)(a): non-disclosure of primary facts gives jurisdiction

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal v. Hemchandra Kar
Commissioner of Income-tax Gujarat v. Bhanji Lavji
Commissioner of Income-tax Calcutta v. Burlop Dealers Ltd.
Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. George Henderson and Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Full value of consideration in sale is actual price paid, not market value

precedents_cited.case_name: Sir Kikabhai Premchand v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Substance over form, but later limited

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Gujarat v. B. M. Kharwar
precedents_cited.relevance: True legal relation determines taxability; disapproved substance overriding legal form cases

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. R. R. Ramakrishna Pillai
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished sale from exchange when shares allotted in satisfaction of money consideration

precedents_cited.case_name: Chittoor Motor Transport Co. (P) Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Chittoor
precedents_cited.relevance: Profit from shares received does not alter sale nature

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court; reassessment jurisdiction; charge and computation of capital gains; full value of consideration

outcome.summary: Both cross-appeals dismissed. Upheld High Court: s.34(1)(a) proceedings valid; capital gains under s.12-B on sale of shares/securities at Rs.75 lakhs full value, computed at Rs.27,04,772; no gains on goodwill or partner admission/share issue.

key_quotes.text: "the full value of the consideration is the full sale price actually paid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines full value under s.12-B(2) for sales

key_quotes.text: "Once all the primary facts are before the assessing authority, it is for him to decide what inferences of facts could be reasonably drawn" - Calcutta Discount
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Clause 1 of the agreement in specific terms says that the existing partners shall sell and the company shall purchase the shares and securities for a sum of Rupees seventy five lakhs."
key_quotes.speaker: court
